close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (complete definition, including fields: options, itc, listen_fd, epoll_fd, epoll_upgrade_fd, was_quiesced, listen_socket_in_epoll)
explanation: We only need the symbols that can affect whether the function parameter 'daemon' (the pointer itself) is modified inside setup_epoll_to_listen. In particular: - struct MHD_Daemon: must see the concrete struct to know which members are being read/written (writing pointed-to members is allowed by the MISRA rule, but reassigning the parameter itself is not). - mhd_assert: it is a macro; its expansion could contain assignments or side effects that modify the local parameter variable. - MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_, MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_, MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_D_DOES_SCKT_FIT_FDSET_: these macros/functions are invoked with 'daemon' (or its members); their definitions must be checked to ensure they do not expand to code that assigns to the parameter variable (e.g., 'daemon = ...') or otherwise change the pointer. - MHD_itc_r_fd_: called with daemon->itc; must ensure it is not a macro that modifies 'daemon' or the pointer parameter. - _MHD_DROP_CONST: macro used in an assignment involving pointers; verify it does not modify the parameter. - MHD_DLOG: logging macro/function takes daemon as first arg; its expansion could have side effects including assignments — verify it does not modify the parameter. - setup_epoll_fd: it's called with daemon; while modifications of the object pointed to are allowed, check its prototype/definition to ensure it is not implemented as a macro that could reassign the caller's local 'daemon' variable via token-pasting or other tricky macro expansion. - epoll_itc_marker: symbol used with _MHD_DROP_CONST; include to see any macro magic that might touch 'daemon'. - MHD_socket typedef and MHD_INVALID_SOCKET: include to confirm types and any macros around these names that could hide side effects. - Option flag definitions (MHD_USE_THREAD_PER_CONNECTION, MHD_USE_AUTO, MHD_ALLOW_UPGRADE): include to rule out any strange macro definitions that could have side effects when used in expressions. These symbols together let an analyst determine whether any macro or inline function used within setup_epoll_to_listen could modify the pointer parameter itself (which would violate the MISRA rule).
